questions.text: What could be the most likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old boy presenting with severe itching, sensitivity to light, and sticky discharge from his eyes. Upon examination the following findings were seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vernal keratoconjunctivitis

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of intense itching and sticky (ropy) discharge, along with the presence of hard, flat-topped papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance as shown in the image are characteristic of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (Spring catarrh):

  • It is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis that tends to occur with the onset of warm weather. It primarily affects young children and adolescents, particularly boys.
  • Type I & IV HSR reaction > Type IV HSR

Course

The condition typically starts in childhood and may resolve on its own over 5–10 years.

Symptoms

Burning, Itching, Photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing).

Signs
  • Palpebral Form: Hypertrophied palpebral conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance; bluish-white color; dense fibrous tissue with thickened epithelium.
  • Limbal or Bulbar Form: Opacification at the limbus, gelatinous thickening, and Horner–Trantas dots

Pseudogerontoxon/cupid’s bow (which resembles arcus senilis) is a grayish-white ring at the limbus seen in severe limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).

  • Shield ulcers are a significant complication of VKC, particularly in severe cases. These microerosions typically form on the upper third of the cornea.
  • Mixed form: Exhibits characteristics of both the tarsal (palpebral) and limbal subtypes, typically presenting in only one eye.
  • Maxwell Lyon's sign is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive mucus deposition on the papilla resulting in cobblestone papillae.

Histology

In the palpebral form, hypertrophied papillae are observed, rich in eosinophils and other inflammatory cells.

Treatment
  • Topical therapy:
    • Antihistamines - Levocabastine & emedastine
    • Mast cell stabilizers - Sodium cromoglicate
    • Mild steroids - Fluorometholone and loteprednol etabonate,
    • Acetylcysteine can control excess mucus.
  • Local therapy: Subtarsal steroid injections and cryotherapy for severe cases.
  • Surgical treatment: Excision of giant papillae and treatment of shield ulcers with debridement and amniotic membrane or bandage contact lens.
  • Cold compresses and tinted glasses for comfort.
  • Avoid eye rubbing

Trachoma (Option A): Sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is seen in Trachoma.

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis (Option C): Type of hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous antigens like bacterial antigens, staphylococcal & tuberculosis antigens. It presents as a small, white, or yellowish nodule (phlyctenule) near the limbus and conjunctival congestion.

Xerophthalmia (Option D): Xerophthalmia is a spectrum of ocular disease caused due to vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by night blindness (earliest feature), conjunctival xerosis, Bitot’s spot, corneal xerosis, ulcer, keratomalacia.

questions.text: The finding seen in the image is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Herbert’s pits:

Explanation:

  • Herbert’s pits are small, shallow depressions seen at the limbal conjunctiva due to healed limbal follicles in trachoma.
  • They are considered pathognomonic of previous trachoma infection.
  • Pathophysiology: Chronic Chlamydia trachomatis infection causes limbal follicles → ulceration → healing with depression.
  • WHO grading: Presence of Herbert’s pits indicates prior active trachoma and is seen in the scarring stage (TS).

Incorrect Options:

Horner-Trantas spots (Option A): White, chalky dots at limbus composed of eosinophils in vernal keratoconjunctivitis, not trachoma.

Pannus (Option C): Superficial vascularization of cornea extending from the limbus, seen in active trachoma and other chronic keratitis.

Arlt’s line (Option D): Linear scar on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, seen in late scarring stage of trachoma, not at the limbus.

questions.text: In a patient who has had contact with a COVID-19 patient, presenting with symptoms such as redness, sensitivity to light, excessive tearing, and overall discomfort, a thorough examination was conducted with no eye abnormality. Based on this information, which specific part of the eye is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Conjunctiva:

  • The symptoms of redness, sensitivity to light (photophobia), excessive tearing, and discomfort are characteristic of conjunctivitis, commonly known as pink eye. Conjunctivitis has been observed as a common ocular manifestation of COVID-19, with the conjunctiva being the most likely part of the eye to be affected. This is usually a mild viral conjunctivitis that resolves with symptomatic treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Uvea (Option B) is typically affected in uveitis. While uveitis can cause redness, sensitivity to light, and discomfort, it is less common to occur solely as a result of COVID-19. Also, uveitis typically presents with more severe signs upon examination, such as cells in the anterior chamber or posterior synechiae, which were not noted in this case.

Choroid (Option C) is a deeper structure within the eye and is not typically affected in viral conjunctivitis or mild ocular manifestations of COVID-19. Choroiditis would present with more severe symptoms and would be visible on specialized imaging such as fluorescein angiography.

Retina (Option D) would typically not be directly affected by COVID-19 or the symptoms presented in this patient. Retinal conditions, such as retinitis, often present with more severe visual changes, such as visual field defects or floaters, which were not reported here.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with fever and swelling of the left eyelid for the past two days. He has no history of trauma but experienced a mild flu-like illness one week ago. On examination, there is no chemosis or protrusion of the eyeball. Based on these observations, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Preseptal cellulitis

Explanation:

  • Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the eyelid and surrounding skin anterior to the orbital septum. It is characterized by eyelid swelling, erythema, fever, and tenderness, often following a minor trauma or spreading from a nearby infection, or spreading from a remote infection of middle ear and upper respiratory tract infection. In this case, the absence of significant ocular findings, such as chemosis or proptosis, along with the mild flu-like illness history, is more consistent with preseptal cellulitis

Chandler’s Classification of Orbital Cellulitis

Stage

Description

Key Features

I - Preseptal cellulitis

Infection confined to the eyelid

Eyelid swelling, no ocular involvement

II - Orbital cellulitis (Option B)

Infection spreads to the orbit

Pain with eye movement, restricted mobility, no abscess formation, chemosis or proptosis

III - Subperiosteal abscess

Pus collection beneath periosteum

Localized pus, proptosis, pain on movement, swelling

IV - Orbital abscess

Pus collection within the orbital tissues

Severe proptosis, potential vision loss, risk of optic nerve damage

V - Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Spread of infection to the cavernous sinus

Bilateral eye involvement, headache, cranial nerve palsies

Panophthalmitis (Option A) It is an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball, including the tenon’s capsule, characterized by severe pain,fever, malaise complete loss of vision, and purulent discharge.

Lid tumor (Option D) refer to abnormal growths or masses in the eyelid.

questions.text: Which statement below does not accurately describe the clinical condition mentioned?

choices.text: Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue
Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen
Destruction of Bowman’s layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctivaoccur.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Destruction of Bowman’s layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea:

Explanation:

  • This statement is not characteristic of pterygium. Bowman's layer is not typically invaded by the pterygium. The pterygium tends to grow over the cornea but does not penetrate Bowman's layer. Instead, it grows between the layers of the cornea, causing distortion and irritation.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue: This statement is correct. Pterygium is associated with abnormal p53 expression, which is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a role in regulating cell growth and preventing the formation of tumors.

Option B - Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen: This statement is correct. Pterygium is associated with an imbalance in the activity of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs), leading to excessive tissue remodeling.

Option D - Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctiva occur: This statement is correct. Pterygium is characterized by elastotic degeneration, which refers to the accumulation of abnormal elastic tissue, and hyalinization, which involves the deposition of a substance called hyaline, in the conjunctival tissue.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Giant papillary conjunctivitis

  • A history of prolonged soft contact lens use, along with symptoms like bilateral itching, redness, watery discharge, and the presence of large, polygonal papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, points towards a diagnosis of Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis.

Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis:

Definition

Specific allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva.

Etiology

  • Soft hydrophilic contact lenses
  • Protruding suture ends
  • Ocular prostheses

Underlying Mechanism

Hypersensitivity reactions (types I and IV)

Symptoms

  • Itching/ Watering
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Occasionally blurred vision

Signs

  • Conjunctival congestion predominantly in the upper palpebral region
  • Large polygonal papillae on superior tarsal conjunctiva
  • Macropapillae (0.3-1.0 mm) and giant papillae (1-2 mm)

Management

  • Discontinue soft contact lenses, remove offending sutures, clean and polish ocular prosthesis; replace with biocompatible material (e.g., Biocoat).
  • Ancillary therapy: Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., lodoxamide, cromolyn sodium, olopatadine) along with artificial tears, antihistaminic drops, and decongestants.

 

Follicular Conjunctivitis (Option A): is the most common clinical form of Viral Conjunctivitis (Adenocirus, Molluscum contagiosum, Herpes simplex, COVID-19). Presents as a milder form of acute conjunctivitis (less symptoms). Follicular appearance of conjunctiva is seen on examination.

Spring Catarrh (Option B): Other name of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (type I & IV > type I hypersensitivity reaction), is characterized by seasonal symptoms, cobblestone-like papillae, limbal thickening with Horner-Trantas dots, and potential corneal involvement, unlike giant papillary conjunctivitis, which typically presents with large papillae associated with contact lens use.

Trachoma (Option D): Sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is seen in Trachoma.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed eye symptom of COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

Explanation:

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Ocular manifestations of COVID-19:

Conjunctiva
  • Follicular conjunctivitis (Most common)
  • Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis
  • Pseudomembrane conjunctivitis

Sclera
  • Scleritis/ Episcleritis

Anterior chamber
  • Anterior Uveitis

Posterior segment
  • Acute macular neuroretinopathy
  • Purtscher-like retinopathy
  • Retinal arterial/venous occlusion (central/branched)

Optic nerve
  • Optic neuritis, optic disc edema

Orbit
  • Sinusitis, Preseptal/Orbital cellulitis

Lacrimal
  • Epiphora

Newborns
  • Periorbital edema (Most common manifestation in newborns)

questions.text: Which of the following treatment options is most frequently used for recurrent pterygium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Conjunctival autograft

Explanation:

A conjunctival autograft (limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or other eye) is the most frequent preferred management for recurrent pterygium.

Management of pterygium:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Management

Reassurance/Observation: if not causing any visual problems (Option C)

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique: (Option D)
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft: (Option A)
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
    • Less recurrence rate
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

questions.text: What is a common ocular finding in pterygium?
questions.solution:
• A pterygium is a fibrovascular growth extending from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, often associated with UV exposure and chronic irritation.
  • The most common visual disturbance caused by a pterygium is astigmatism, due to its pulling effect on the cornea, leading to corneal distortion and irregular refraction.

 

Eye pain (Option A): Pterygium can cause irritation, foreign body sensation, and redness, but severe pain is not a primary feature. Pain occurs only if there is inflammation or ulceration.

 

Macular edema (Option B): Pterygium affects the cornea and conjunctiva, but it does not involve the retina or macula. Macular edema is seen in conditions like diabetic retinopathy or retinal vein occlusion.

 

Purulent discharge (Option C): Pterygium is a non-infectious degenerative condition, so it does not cause purulent discharge. Discharge may be seen in bacterial conjunctivitis or dacryocystitis.

 

Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

Pseudopterygium
 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.

 
  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process
  • Pterygium like lesion
  • Due to cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth
 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons
  • Seen at any age
  • Caused by
    • Trauma
    • Chronic conjunctivitis
    • Thermochemical burn




 

Pathology

 

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

  
 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane
  


 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflammed pterygium

 
  • Non-progressive
  • Can be at any quadrant of the corneal limbus
  • Located away from the horizontal
  • Attached to the cornea due to scar tissue
  • Adhered to the adjacent lid
  • Always stationary

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.

 
  • A probe can be passed under the neck.

Management of pterygium:






 

Management

Best left alone

 

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia







 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique:
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or
    • An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who wears contact lenses and has been experiencing eye watering, redness, and a sensation of having a foreign object in the eye for the last two months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

Explanation:

A history of prolonged soft contact lens use, along with symptoms like bilateral itching, redness, watery discharge, and the presence of large, polygonal papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, points towards a diagnosis of Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis.

 

Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis:

Definition

Specific allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva.

Etiology

  • Soft hydrophilic contact lenses
  • Protruding suture ends
  • Ocular prostheses

Underlying Mechanism

Hypersensitivity reactions (types I and IV)

Symptoms

  • Itching/ Watering
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Occasionally blurred vision

Signs

  • Conjunctival congestion predominantly in the upper palpebral region
  • Large polygonal papillae on superior tarsal conjunctiva
  • Macropapillae (0.3-1.0 mm) and giant papillae (1-2 mm)

Management

  • Discontinue soft contact lenses, remove offending sutures, clean and polish ocular prosthesis; replace with biocompatible material (e.g., Biocoat).
  • Ancillary therapy: Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., lodoxamide, cromolyn sodium, olopatadine) along with artificial tears, antihistaminic drops, and decongestants.

 

 

Follicular Conjunctivitis (Option A): is the most common clinical form of Viral Conjunctivitis (Adenocirus, Molluscum contagiosum, Herpes simplex, COVID-19). Presents as a milder form of acute conjunctivitis (less symptoms). Follicular appearance of conjunctiva is seen on examination.

 

Spring Catarrh (Option B): Other name of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (type I & IV > type I hypersensitivity reaction), is characterized by seasonal symptoms, cobblestone-like papillae, limbal thickening with Horner-Trantas dots, and potential corneal involvement, unlike giant papillary conjunctivitis, which typically presents with large papillae associated with contact lens use.

 

Trachoma (Option D): Sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is seen in Trachoma.

questions.text: What could be the probable diagnosis for the eye lesion observed in a 21-year-old male patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bitot’s spots

Explanation:

The provided image illustrates Bitot spots belonging to the X1B classification of xerophthalmia.

Classification of Xerophthalmia:

 

Stage

Description

XN

Night blindness: Difficulty seeing in low light or at night.

X1A

Conjunctival xerosis: Dryness of the conjunctiva without foamy patches (Bitot spots).

X1B

Bitot spots: Presence of foamy, whitish accumulations on the conjunctiva (Option A)

X2

Corneal xerosis: The cornea's dryness makes it appear dull and hazy.

X3A

Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia (<1/3rd of the cornea)

X3B

Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia (>1/3rd of the cornea)

XS

Corneal scar: Scarring of the cornea resulting from the healing of ulcers or keratomalacia.

XF

Xerophthalmic fundus: Retinal changes associated with chronic Vitamin A deficiency.
  • The stages from X1A to X2 are reversible.

Pterygium (Option B): Pterygium is a degenerative, subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. May cause visual disturbances.

 

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis (Option C): Type of hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous antigens like bacterial antigens, staphylococcal & tuberculosis antigens. It presents as a small, white, or yellowish nodule (phlyctenule) near the limbus and conjunctival congestion.

Pinguecula (Option D): Pinguecula is a yellowish-white mound near the limbus formed by elastotic degeneration of conjunctival stroma. Only a cosmetic defect, does not cause any vision problems.

questions.text: What is the causative agent of the sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chlamydia trachomatis

Explanation:

The sago grain appearance of the follicles in conjunctiva is seen in the active stage of trachoma and the organism responsible is Chlamydia trachomatis.

Clinical features of Trachoma:

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva: Look like sago-grains
  • Papillary enlargement: red, velvety

Conjunctival signs:

  • Scarring
    • It may be irregular, star-shaped, or linear
    • Linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt’s line
  • accumulation of dead epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in the glands of Henle
  • Pseudocyst
  • Xerosis
  • Symblepharon

Corneal signs:

  • Superficial keratitis on slit lamp and fluorescein
  • Herbert’s follicles
  • Progressive pannus/Trachomatous pannus: The upper part of the cornea is cloudy
  • Corneal ulcers are common at the advancing edge of the pannus
    • Shallow, little infiltrated
    • Cause lacrimation and photophobia

Corneal signs:

  • Regressive pannus or pannus siccus:
    • Receding infiltration
    • Vessels extend beyond the area of infiltration and haze
  • Herbert pits: oval or circular pitted scars formed after the healing of Herbert’s follicles in the limbal area
  • Vascularized and opaque cornea.
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae)

 

 

Lid signs:

  • Distortion of the lids
  • Tylosis: Thickening of the tarsal plate/lid margin
  • Trichiasis: due to rubbing of lashes on the cornea
  • Trachomatous ptosis (sleepy appearance)
  • Entropion
  • Madarosis
  • Ankyloblepharon

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Herbert pits:

  • The image shows scarring in the upper limbus, which is referred to as Herbert's pits. It is seen in the chronic cicatricial stage of trachoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Horner trantas spots:

Option C – Pannus:

Option D - Corneal dystrophy:

                                                                                       Microcystic/Map dot/ Fingerprint Dystrophy

                                                                              Meesmann dystrophy

 

                                                            Reis-Bucklers corneal dystrophy

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Limbal dermoid:

  • Limbal dermoids are congenital benign tumors that cause astigmatism, encroachment on the visual axis, and fatty component infiltration into the cornea. They consist of overgrowths of epidermal appendages, connective tissues, skin, fat, sweat glands, lacrimal glands, and neurologic tissues located partly over the cornea and partly over the sclera.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pterygium: A pterygium is a fibrovascular growth of the conjunctiva that extends onto the cornea.

Option C - Pyogenic granuloma: A pyogenic granuloma is a red, fleshy, vascular lesion that usually arises after trauma or surgery.

Option D - Pinguecula: A pinguecula is a yellowish, slightly raised lesion on the conjunctiva, usually near the limbus.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed eye symptom associated with COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option C)

Explanation

The most frequently observed eye symptom associated with COVID-19 is follicular conjunctivitis.

Follicular conjunctivitis typically presents with redness, swelling, and irritation of the conjunctiva, along with a follicular reaction on the palpebral conjunctiva. This condition has been reported in patients with COVID-19, and it is often associated with other symptoms of viral infection.

Ophthalmic conditions associated with COVID-19

Category

Conditions

Conjunctiva
  • Acute conjunctivitis
  • Unremitting conjunctivitis
  • Mild follicular conjunctivitis
  • Severe hemorrhagic conjunctivitis
  • Pseudomembrane formation
  • Keratoconjunctivitis
  • Kawasaki-like illness (MIS-C)

Sclera/Episclera
  • Episcleritis
  • Nodular episcleritis
  • Necrotizing anterior scleritis
  • Sectoral anterior scleritis

Anterior Chamber
  • Acute anterior uveitis
  • Reactivated idiopathic anterior uveitis

Retina and Choroid
  • Central retinal vein occlusion
  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Acute macular neuroretinopathy (AMN)
  • Paracentral acute middle maculopathy (PAMM)
  • Purtscher-like retinopathy
  • Retinal hemorrhages
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Dilated veins
  • Tortuous vessels
  • Multifocal choroiditis (associated with vaccine)
  • Serpiginous and ampiginous choroiditis
  • Acute retinal necrosis (due to herpes virus reactivation)
  • Retinal vasculitis
  • Retinal degeneration
  • Breakdown of blood-retinal barrier

Optic Nerve
  • Optic neuritis
  • Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder
  • Anti-myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (anti-MOG) antibodies
  • Papilledema
  • Elevated intracranial pressure (pseudotumor cerebri syndrome)

Extraocular Motility, Cranial Nerves
  • Cranial nerve III, IV, VI palsies
  • Binocular diplopia
  • Ocular cranial neuropathies
  • Postinfectious demyelinating conditions (e.g., Miller-Fisher syndrome, Guillain-Barré syndrome)
  • Ocular myasthenia gravis

Pupils
  • Mydriasis
  • Cholinergic super-sensitivity
  • Tonic pupils

Nystagmus
  • Visual disturbances (oscillopsia)
  • Viral-induced vestibular neuritis
  • Central vestibular nystagmus (associated with rhombencephalitis)

Visual Cortex
  • Acute stroke affecting posterior visual pathways
  • Homonymous visual field deficits
  • Posterior cerebral artery ischemic strokes

Orbit and Ocular Adnexa
  • Sinusitis
  • Orbital cellulitis
  • Bacterial orbital abscess
  • Invasive fungal rhino-orbital mucormycosis
  • Orbital myositis

Lacrimal System
  • Epiphora (tear overproduction)

Manifestations in Newborn Infants
  • Periorbital edema
  • Chemosis
  • Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis
  • Ciliary injection
  • Corneal edema
  • Rubeosis
  • Posterior synechiae
  • Retinopathy of prematurity
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Cotton wool spots

 

Uveitis (Option A): While uveitis can occur in some cases of COVID-19, it is not the most frequent eye symptom. Uveitis refers to inflammation of the uveal tract (the iris, ciliary body, and choroid), and while it has been reported in some COVID-19 patients, it is less common than conjunctivitis.

 

Mucormycosis (Option B): This is a rare fungal infection that can occur in COVID-19 patients, particularly in those with diabetes or who are immunocompromised. It can cause serious orbital and sinus involvement, but it is not the most frequently observed eye symptom in COVID-19.

 

Papillary conjunctivitis (Option D): This refers to inflammation of the conjunctiva with prominent papillae (small, raised bumps) on the inner surface of the eyelids. While it can occur in various infections, it is not as commonly reported as follicular conjunctivitis in COVID-19.

questions.text: A young boy from a poor socioeconomic background presents with hyperemia and yellowish nodules at the limbus. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

Explanation: Poor socioeconomic status suggests that the person is prone to develop infections. The above image is of Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis

Cause

Allergic reactions to endogenous antigens are often linked to bacterial infections such as Staphylococcus aureus (M/C/C in Western countries) or tuberculosis(M/C/C in India).

Symptoms & signs
  • Watering, itching
  • Reflex blepharospasm (involuntary blinking)
  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Phlycten - Small, round, grayish, or yellowish nodules on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus.
  • Corneal involvement can lead to fascicular ulcers or ring ulcers.

Pathophysiology

Type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

Common Complications

Corneal involvement: Ulcers form on the cornea, leading to potential scarring.

Associated Conditions

Long-standing mild infections like tonsillitis or adenoiditis, and in populations with a high prevalence of tuberculosis.

Treatment

Local therapy:

  • Corticosteroids: Drops/ointment to reduce inflammation. Address underlying cause (e.g., tuberculosis).
  • Antibiotics
  • Cycloplegics: Paralyze ciliary muscle, relieve pain, and prevent complications.
  • Dark Glasses/Eye Shade: For photophobia relief.

General therapy:

  • Oral tetracycline or doxycycline is used in recurrent cases linked to Staphylococcal blepharitis.

Supportive: Dark glasses or eye shade.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with Vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bitot’s spots

Explanation:

Causes for Vitamin A Deficiency :

  • Decreased intake.
  • Obstructive jaundice: Defective absorption.
  • Liver cirrhosis: Reduce synthesis of RBP (retinol binding protein).
  • Severe malnutrition: Lack of amino acids for RBP synthesis.
  • Chronic nephrosis: RBP excretion through urine.

Vitamin A Deficiency Manifestations :

1. Ocular manifestations :

  • Vitamin A deficiency is the most significant preventable cause of blindness, especially in children below 5 in developing countries.
  • Early Signs:
    • Loss of sensitivity to green light.
    • Difficulty adapting to dim light.
    • Night blindness.
  • Prolonged Deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia:
      • Dry, thick, keratinized conjunctiva and cornea. If untreated, it leads to corneal ulceration and ultimately results in blindness due to the formation of opaque scar tissue.
      • WHO grading of xerophthalmia:
      • Bitot's Spots: Grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva.
      • Keratomalacia: When xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia (corneal softening).

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots. (Option B)

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.

2. Immune Function:

  • Deficiency increases susceptibility to infections.
  • Infection reduces retinol-binding protein synthesis, lowering vitamin A levels and impairing immune responses.

3. Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:

  • Follicular Hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): Causes rough skin due to hyperkeratinization of the follicular epithelium.
  • Keratinizing Metaplasia: Affects respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary tracts.
  • Epithelium is atrophied.

4. Other General Manifestation :

  • Growth retardation due to defective synthesis of chondroitin sulfate.
  • Decreased protein synthesis.

Incorrect Options:

Pinguecula (Option A) is a degenerative conjunctival condition unrelated to Vitamin A deficiency.

Pterygium (Option C) is a fibrovascular growth extending from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, often caused by UV exposure rather than nutritional deficiency.

Stocker’s line (Option D) is an iron line seen in front of the advancing edge of a pterygium, also unrelated to Vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is the normal conjunctival flora?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Staph Epidermidis

Explanation:

  • The normal conjunctival flora is Staph Epidermidis
  • Staph Epidermidis is the most common organism which is responsible for Acute Onset Endophthalmitis.

Acute endophthalmitis:

Definition
  • Inflammation of inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers. It spares sclera.
  • Acute bacterial endophthalmitis happens 1-7 days post intraocular surgery.

M/C causative organism
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option B)

Presentation

  • Severe ocular pain
  • Redness
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Loss of vision
  • Red and swollen lids
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Circumcorneal congestion
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Ring infiltration
  • Yellow necrotic wound edges
  • Hypopyon
  • Oedematous and muddy iris
  • Yellow pupil reflex due to purulent exudation
  • Vitreous exudation which causes amaurotic cat's-eye reflex
  • Raised intraocular pressure initially

Treatment

  • Intravitreal antibiotics:
    • First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Ceftazidime 2.25 mg
    • Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Amikacin 0.4 mg
  • Topical antibiotics
  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Steroid Therapy
  • Supportive Therapy
  • Vitrectomy - if no improvement in 48-72 hours or if severe infection with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face
  • If blind - no perception of light - Evisceration.

Options A, C & D: Staph aureus, Strep. Pneumonia and H. influenzae are disease causing bacteria and do not form the normal conjunctival flora

questions.text: What is the causative agent of the ocular condition as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chlamydia

Explanation:

The ocular condition shown in the image is active trachoma, which is caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Trachoma is a leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide, particularly in areas with poor sanitation.

 

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva: Look like sago-grains
  • Papillary enlargement: red, velvety

Conjunctival signs:

  • Scarring
    • It may be irregular, star-shaped, or linear
    • Linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt’s line
  • accumulation of dead epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in the glands of Henle
  • Pseudocyst
  • Xerosis
  • Symblepharon

Corneal signs:

  • Superficial keratitis on slit lamp and fluorescein
  • Herbert’s follicles
  • Progressive pannus/Trachomatous pannus: The upper part of the cornea is cloudy
  • Corneal ulcers are common at the advancing edge of the pannus
    • Shallow, little infiltrated
    • Cause lacrimation and photophobia

Corneal signs:

  • Regressive pannus or pannus siccus:
    • Receding infiltration
    • Vessels extend beyond the area of infiltration and haze
  • Herbert pits: oval or circular pitted scars formed after the healing of Herbert’s follicles in the limbal area
  • Vascularized and opaque cornea.
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae)

 

 

Lid signs:

  • Distortion of the lids
  • Tylosis: Thickening of the tarsal plate/lid margin
  • Trichiasis due to rubbing of lashes on the cornea
  • Trachomatous ptosis (sleepy appearance)
  • Entropion
  • Madarosis
  • Ankyloblepharon

Lacrimal apparatus sequelae:

  • Chronic dacryocystitis
  • Chronic dacryoadenitis

 

Images:

Active Trachoma

Follicles in upper palpebral conjunctiva

 

Progressive pannus

Cicatricial

Trachoma

Regressive pannus

Conjunctival concretions

Trichiasis

Tylosis (thickening of tarsal border of eyelid)

 

WHO Classification of Trachoma (FISTO)

Stage

Description

Image

Management

TF:

Trachomatous Inflammation- Follicular

  • The presence of five or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Active stage of trachoma
  • Antibiotics to eliminate the organism
  • Topical:
    • Tetracycline 1% or
    • Erythromycin 1%
    • Sulfacetamide
  • Systemic:
    • Tetracycline or erythromycin orally
    • Doxycycline orally
    • Azithromycin single oral dose
  • Combined systemic and topical therapy:
    • For TI or when an associated genital infection is present
    • Tetracycline 1% or erythromycin 1% eye ointment
    • Azithromycin orally

TI: Trachamatous Inflammation- Intense

Pronounced inflammatory thickening of the tarsal conjunctiva that obscures more than half of the normal deep tarsal vessels.

TS: Trachamatous Scarring

  • Presence of scarring in tarsal conjunctiva
  • White, bands or sheets of fibrosis in tarsal conjunctiva
  • Concretions removed with a hypodermic needle
  • Conjunctival xerosis with artificial tears (lubricating drops)

TT: Trachamatous Trichiasis

At least one eyelash rub on eyeball or evidence of recent removal of inturned eyelashes.
  • Permanent lash removal:
    • Electrolysis
    • Cryolysis
    • Radiofrequency epilation
    • Bilamellar tarsal resection
  • Cicatricial entropion surgery

CO: Corneal Opacity
  • Easily visible corneal opacity over the pupil
  • Part of the pupil margin is blurred when seen through the opacity as it is very dense corneal scarring
  • After treatment of other trachoma sequelae
  • Penetrating keratoplasty for significant corneal scarring
  • Keratoprosthesis for bilateral blind cases with extensive scarring and surface problems
  • Punctal occlusion and lateral tarsorrhaphy for coexistent eye surface problems

Mycoplasma (Option B): Although Mycoplasma can cause some ocular infections, it is not the causative agent of trachoma.

Pseudomonas (Option C): This is a common pathogen in corneal ulcers or infections, but it is not responsible for trachoma.

Staphylococcus (Option D: Staphylococcus infections can cause conjunctivitis and other eye conditions, but it is not the causative agent of trachoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of pterygium?

choices.text: The parts of a pterygium are the head, neck and body

questions.solution:
• Pterygium is a fibrovascular growth that arises from the conjunctiva and extends onto the cornea, typically affecting the nasal side of the eye. (Option B ruled out)
  • The parts of a pterygium include: (Option C ruled out)
    • Head: The part that grows onto the cornea.
    • Neck: The transition zone between the conjunctiva and the cornea.
    • Body: The part on the conjunctiva.
  • Pterygium has progressive and regressive types, meaning it can either grow over time (progressive) or shrink back (regressive) in some cases. (Option D ruled out)
  • The rate of recurrence after surgical removal of pterygium is typically around 30-40%, not 95%. This high rate of recurrence is more common in certain settings (e.g., incomplete excision or lack of adjunctive treatments like conjunctival autografting or mitomycin C). A 95% recurrence rate is uncharacteristically high and is not the typical outcome. (Option A)

Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

Pseudopterygium
 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.

  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process
  • Pterygium like lesion
  • Due to cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth
 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons
  • Seen at any age
  • Caused by
    • Trauma
    • Chronic conjunctivitis
    • Thermochemical burn
 

Pathology

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

  
 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane
  


 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflamed pterygium
  • Non-progressive
  • Can be at any quadrant of the corneal limbus
  • Located away from the horizontal
  • Attached to the cornea due to scar tissue
  • Adhered to the adjacent lid
  • Always stationary

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.

 
  • A probe can be passed under the neck.

questions.text: What is the recommended approach for managing a middle-aged woman with a progressive pterygium that is extending towards the pupillary area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Excision with conjunctival autograft:

  • The most appropriate management for pterygium encroaching the pupillary area is surgical excision with conjunctival autograft. 
  • This involves removing the pterygium tissue and replacing it with a graft of healthy conjunctival tissue taken from another area of the patient's own eye. 
  • This procedure has been shown to have a low recurrence rate and a high success rate in preventing visual disturbance caused by the pterygium.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Keratoplasty: Keratoplasty involves the surgical replacement of the cornea with a healthy donor cornea. Indicated for corneal opacities, bullous keratoplasty, corneal dystrophies, and keratoconus.

Option C - Observation: If the pterygium is not causing any visual disturbance, observation may be appropriate. However, if it is steadily progressing towards the pupillary area, it is likely to cause visual disturbances and should be managed surgically.

Option D - Beta-radiation: Beta-radiation therapy involves using low doses of radiation to prevent recurrence of the pterygium, not recommended.

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment for a patient who experiences considerable discomfort when reading text from paper or a screen, despite having normal visual acuity and other eye examination findings, except for a Schirmer's test result of 5mm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lubricating eye drops:

  • A low Schirmer's test value of 5 mm (15 mm normal value)indicates reduced tear production and dry eye syndrome. 
  • Lubricants such as artificial tears like cellulose derivatives alleviate dry eye symptoms and improve visual comfort. They work by supplementing the natural tears, improving tear film stability, and reducing ocular surface inflammation.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. They are not used for the management of Scirmer’s test.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old boy who is experiencing severe itching, and thick discharge from his eyes. Upon examination the following finding as shown in the image was observed.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Vernal keratoconjunctivitis:

  • The patient's symptoms of intense itching and thick ropy discharge, along with the presence of hard, flat-topped papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance, are characteristic of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trachoma: Trachoma is a chronic, infectious form of conjunctivitis caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. It is characterized by conjunctival scarring, trichiasis, and corneal opacity, which can lead to blindness if left untreated.

Option C - Phlyctenular conjunctivitis: Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type of hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous antigens like staphylococcal & tuberculosis antigen, typically seen in children. It presents as a small, white, or yellowish nodule (phlyctenule) near limbus and conjunctival congestion..

Option D - Xerophthalmia: Xerophthalmia is a condition caused by severe vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by dryness and thickening of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can lead to corneal ulceration and blindness.

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vernal keratoconjunctivitis:

  • The given image is suggestive of conjunctival congestion and is suggestive of vernal keratoconjunctivitis, a chronic allergic condition that primarily affects the conjunctiva.
  • It is characterized by recurrent episodes of inflammation, itching, redness, and a cobblestone-like appearance on the upper palpebral conjunctiva..
  • This condition is more common in young individuals, particularly boys, and is often associated with a history of allergies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Herpes simplex keratitis: Herpes simplex keratitis is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus characterized by redness, and dendritic or branching pattern of corneal ulcers.

Option B - Bacterial keratitis: It usually presents with symptoms such as eye redness, pain, discharge, hypopyon, and a corneal infiltrate or ulcer.

Option C - Mycotic keratitis: It usually presents with redness, pain, discharge, unsterile hypopyon and dry corneal ulcer with feathery ends.

questions.text: What is the cause of phlyctenular conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Tuberculous proteins:

  • Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is most commonly associated with a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous microbial proteins.
  • Endogenous microbial proteins are:
    • Tuberculous proteins.
    • Staphylococcal proteins.
    • Moraxella Axenfeld bacillus and certain parasites.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atropine: It is known to cause contact dermatoconjunctivitis.

Option B - Asthma: Asthma (atopy) is known to cause atopic keratoconjunctivitis and some cases of vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

Option C - Contact lens: It is known to cause giant papillary conjunctivitis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pterygium:

  • The given image reveals fleshy growth extending onto the cornea.
  • Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.It appears as a triangular or wedge-shaped fleshy growth on the inner or outer side of the eye, usually starting from the conjunctiva near the nasal or temporal side (nasal more common).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pinguecula: A pinguecula is a yellowish, elevated growth on the conjunctiva, but it does not extend onto the cornea..

Option B - Concretions: Concretions refer to tiny calcium or protein deposits that can form on the conjunctiva.

Option D - Bitot's Spots: Bitot's spots are a specific manifestation of vitamin A deficiency. They appear as small, foamy, irregularly shaped white or grayish patches on the conjunctiva, typically located on the temporal side of the eye.

questions.text: Which microorganism is responsible for angular conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Moraxella lacunata:

  • Angular conjunctivitis, also known as angular blepharitis or angular keratoconjunctivitis, is commonly caused by the bacterium Moraxella lacunata.
  • It is characterized by inflammation and infection of the canthi(angles) of the eyes, resulting in redness, discharge, and crusting.
  • Other pathogens causing angular conjunctivitis are:
    • Moraxella axenfeld (most common).
    • Moraxella catarrhalis.
    • Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These organisms do not cause angular conjunctivitis.

questions.text: In developed countries, what is the primary etiology responsible for ophthalmia neonatorum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chlamydia:

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum worldwide..
  • Ophthalmia neonatorum refers to conjunctivitis that occurs in newborn babies within the first month of life.
  • Chlamydial ophthalmia neonatorum is typically acquired during delivery when the baby comes into contact with the infected birth canal.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gonorrhoea: Neisseria gonorrhoeae can manifest with severe symptoms of ophthalmia neonatorum, but is less common than chlamydia.

Option C - Chemical conjunctivitis: Chemical conjunctivitis refers to conjunctival inflammation caused by exposure to irritants or chemicals which are given as a prophylaxis for conjunctivitis.

Option D - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause various types of infections, including conjunctivitis, but it is not the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum.

questions.text: What is the underlying factor responsible for the development of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Enterovirus 70: Viral causes of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis are:

  • Enterovirus - 70
  • Adenovirus
  • Coxsackie - 24
  • Echovirus - 34

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D do not cause hemorrhagic conjunctivitis

questions.text: True about pterygium:

choices.text: Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

questions.solution:
Correct option C - Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea:

  • A pterygium is a fibrovascular sub-epithelial ingrowth of degenrative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea.
  • It appears as a triangular-shaped tissue with blood vessels and can cause discomfort, redness, and visual disturbances. It is characterized by the invasion of conjunctival tissue over the cornea, forming a flap-like structure.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Pterygium is a sub epithelial of conjunctiva on the cornea like a flap.
